comments.commentBody: Mr. Winter made some wonderful photographs using a simple tool. His explanation of what and how he proceeded to make the photographs was exactly right and honest to the core. He is the last man standing tall. At risk of perhaps going over the top -- I would have awarded him first place for making unique photographs of vision that live within the narrow corridor of classic photojournalism. New tools still need old rules and he stayed within that point of honor. I say -- good for you Mr. Winter and Spring is just around the corner. Eli Reed/Magnum Photos/Professor of Photojournalism, University of Texas at Austin

The nature and extent of Madoff's Ponzi scheme was reported to all of the financial news outlets and the SEC two years or more before he was "uncovered." Everyone knew, or should have known, with the exercise of reasonable prudence, what he was doing. The investor class chose to disregard the truth. They were not to be trusted then and they are not to be trusted now.

The excuse for fraud and deceit is always that the investors are seasoned and know the risks. Perhaps some of them do, but what of all the small plumbers, for example, who invested with BM. They had no way of knowing. As long as the government of the people allows the investment industry to treat people like this, we will continue to have crash after crash.

Until we decide that the purpose of the Market is to provide for the development of our economy, and not just to make investment gamblers rich, we will continue to suffer periodic collapses that damage us. The sad thing is that we may never regain our premier position in the World because of the latest shenanigans of the industry.
Why should we believe a word this felon says? I think he has given up his right to an audience with all the misinformation and dishonesty he puts out.

Madoff's reaction is precisely what one would expect from a malignant narcissist; a web of lies, a complete lack of empathy and a sense of rage over the loss of narcissistic supply and the injustice of his current circumstances.
Of course he is passing the buck over to the deep pocketed banks and hedge funds in an attempt to protect his obviously complicit friends and family.

The only revelation in this piece is that the trustee, who should be commended for ferociously recovering assets from those complicit in this monstrous fraud no longer has any justification for clawing back from the long term innocent investor. The innocent long term Madoff investor, mostly elderly and widows, will never share in the recovery, had their SIPC claims denied and would be rendered destitute by these persecutory clawbacks. They should now be left alone.
Did Madoff come with the social security pyramid scheme as well?
Missed a chance for growth? Lucky them. Growth in these terms doesn't really help anyone.
Why is anything this man says worth the moment it took to listen to it? Get him off the front page and back into solitary.
The banks, everybody knew Bernie -- he was good, they knew that, just don't ask and everything will work out, you'll see.

A former Ambassador to Tunisia and Egypt gave a very informative lecture here last week. He had many useful insights into the recent upheavals sweeping from west to east in the Muslim world. This was not the usual boilerplate about "stability" and "the balance of power." The speaker was an experienced State Department career professional. He emphasized the roles played by rapid population growth and the consequent youthful demographic throughout the Middle East, and the activist role played by unemployed college graduates in Tunisia's uprising. At the Q & A session, I asked him; "It seems that modernizing the economy is one of the better ways to employ large numbers of young people in a rapidly growing population. In the last 30 years China and India have modernized economically because internal forces decided to, not because someone from the West told them that they ought to. What are the chances internal movements to modernize the economy will arise in Egypt or another Arab country?"

He indicated that's possible but that Muslim cultures are still held back by having one foot planted so firmly in the past.

As cultural center of the Arab world, Egypt is more sophisticated than most of its neighbors. It needs a Shenzhen or Bangalore very badly. Remaining enamored with a fabled past means remaining mired in backwardness and struggling with unmanageable population growth. Unfortunate countries often blame their troubles on the West, but it doesn't solve much. China and India seem to have gotten over it. Maybe a few Middle Eastern countries could do the same.

When, in this timeline, did the SEC receive its first whistleblower letter?  I have heard stories of financially savvy people who know Madoff investors and asked for details, the lack of which set off alarm bells.  When did the first of them try to bring this to the attention of the authorities?

He has zero credibility.

Why should we believe anything he says?

They guy is a psychopath who is incapable of either being honest or having any empathy for his victims. If he had ever cared about his family, he would not have brought them into the scam in the first place. As to the banks, the SEC was given a list of firms that knew about Madoff, a few years before the fraud was exposed. Madoff is such an egomaniac, he still believes that he is smarter than everyone else.

Bernie has such a sense of fairness:  Once Picard gets $20 billion back, Bernie says, Picard should just shut the office down and call it even.  I can understand people sticking with a product that "seemed too good to be true."  We've all been there.  But I can't comprehend how sick and twisted a man must be to run a 16 year ponzi scheme, completely shaft his friends and family, and now live on with no remorse, only self serving lies.
Why NYtimes did not have an investigative on him? just like why there was not any worthy reporting before the Iraq war from this paper?

note also the court appointed former governor cuomo to mediate between the trustee and mets owner. they don't want them to spill the beans.

you ever noticed how qucikly the court wrapped up the madoff case?
To tell the truth, who would believe a word this man says, for the truth is but a childhood memory for him now.

Does anyone really believe the SEC didn't know what was going on? The people in charge of oversight did not do their jobs & should be indicted for looking the other way. This includes Paulson and every manager of those funds. Too big to fail---too big for JAIL!  Taxpayers are always the suckers.

Ah ha.. now that the 65B (or whatever the amount was) has vanished, he wants to make sure the 'victims' collect from the Banks to double the take?

This will go down in history as the largest organized scam of all times.
There've been plenty of indications that the Administration wasn't going to allow anything to stand in the way of their period of record economic growth.

Ambivalent-conundrum?

1. I certainly do not trust the banks, surely not after this economic depression which is brought about by honest bankers and hedge fund operators

2. I assuredly will not trust a felon, a monumental swindler and a pyramid king and schemer

But, I will rather take Bernie Madoff's word over too big-to-fail banks/bankers

While I remain deeply suspicious of banks, financial institutions and get-rich-quick pyramid schemers!

What is that term again? Trust but verify?

This article contained two sentences which rather surprised me.

The first quite speculative:

"Mr. Madoff, who is serving a 150-year sentence, seemed frail and a bit agitated compared with the stoic calm he maintained before his incarceration in 2009, perhaps burdened by sadness over the suicide of his son Mark in December."

The second quite self-promotional:

"Both the interview and the e-mail correspondence were conducted as part of this reporter’s research for a coming book on the Madoff scandal, “The Wizard of Lies: Bernie Madoff and the Death of Trust,” for publication this spring by Times Books, a division of Henry Holt & Company."

The Times, they is a-changin'.
Balderdash! I don't believe a word that Madoff says. (Including his assertions that his family didn't know. He's only saying that to protect them and their ill-gotten assets.)

In Egypt, where only about 3% of the land is arable (the Nile Valley and a few scattered oases), the disappearance of farmland to semi-urban sprawl is a huge threat to the country's agricultural productivity. The government has been trying to combat this by building desert satellite cities and industrial zones outside of the Nile Valley, such as October 6th City, but these satellite cities still don't have the infrastructure, jobs, and public transportation to draw large numbers of citizens out there. In most satellite cities, you need a car to get around easily, which is beyond the means of most Egyptians.

Instead, the wealthy have been expanding into the semi-arable areas to build vast gated communities replete with golf courses and other questionable uses of Egypt's limited water resources. Although the government is clearly aware of the problems of constraints on land and water, some of its moves (influenced by business interests) have been disastrous, such as building a huge irrigation canal stretching hundreds of miles out into the desert to the Toshka agricultural project on the Sudanese border. Predictably, the evaporation loss rate is very high.

it's the usual scenario.  after a period of time prison loses its cache and small niceties become very alluring. Bernie is there anyone you can think of that may have been complicit? how about a name for a view,some sex, HBO? a book deal?

I feel real sadness when I read this story. Especially about his son Mark, who passed recently. His actions have influenced so many, had so many consequences. Honestly I wonder if some people, who do things like this, 'know' they are doing wrong, but somehow are not able to get in touch with the possible consequences until it is too late for them.

He seems broken and sad from this whole ordeal. I do feel sadness for the soul who he is, that each person is worthy and capable of redemption.
